values.title: Build -dev and -dbg debs

content.raw: We should provide -dev and -dbg debs for everything we release.

values.title: Deb build jobs should pull tarball

content.raw: debbuild jobs currently pull from Mercurial at a given tag (and that's done sort of manually due to an apparent bug in Jenkins's Mercurial plugin).  Instead, they should just grab the tarball that was made and uploaded by the release script.
content.html: debbuild jobs currently pull from Mercurial at a given tag (and that's done sort of manually due to an apparent bug in Jenkins's Mercurial plugin). Instead, they should just grab the tarball that was made and uploaded by the release script.

values.title: Source packages aren't being uploaded

content.raw: At the moment, the debbuild jobs are just invoking `reprepro includedeb ...` to insert the specific binary deb that was built.  They're not inserting the .dsc or any .tar.* or .changes.* files.  Figure out what the right way is to do this when the binary debs are built by different jobs.  Probably something like the ROS build farm, where a separate sourcedeb job kicks off binary debbuild jobs.
content.html: At the moment, the debbuild jobs are just invoking reprepro includedeb ... to insert the specific binary deb that was built. They're not inserting the .dsc or any .tar. or .changes. files. Figure out what the right way is to do this when the binary debs are built by different jobs. Probably something like the ROS build farm, where a separate sourcedeb job kicks off binary debbuild jobs.

values.title: old .debs should be archived

content.raw: reprepro seems to throw away old debs when new ones are inserted into a repo.  We should maintain an archive (just a simple web-accessible directory would do) of old .debs.  The upload step should be inserted into the debbuild jobs.

values.title: Make cpack clone or archive local repo to replace CPACK_SOURCE_IGNORE_FILES usage

content.raw:
Currently, gazebo or drcsim use `CPACK_SOURCE_IGNORE_FILES` during a release, but it might be better if the release process includes `hg archive` of the working directory, or `hg clone` and `hg up -b [current branch name]`.

As `CPACK_SOURCE_IGNORE_FILES` might sometimes miss some non-standard build directories (e.g. `build_debug`, ...)

values.title: Speed up the release process

content.raw:
Currently our release process especially for gazebo. Here are my thoughts about why is so slow and how can we improve it:

### Why is currently slow? ###

* It can only run in one of the jenkins slave nodes, where the credentials to upload packages to gazebosim and real repo packages.osrfoundation.org is hosted.
* For gazebo, it can only be compiled using -j1 because of large amount of memory needed for multiple thread. This started when we add all the possible support (player, media libs, etc) inside the build.

### What can be done to speed up the process? ###

* Set up several machines to build packages. One option could be set up all slaves to build and upload packages to gazebosim and trigger a jenkins job at the node where the repo is hosted which will download the new package and set it up in the repo using reprepro.
* Enable multiple compilation threads. This will need a research about why are we using those large amounts of memory and see if they are really needed. I suspect that sometimes we are abusing of linking libraries not needed. And, of course, the easy way, buy more memory.
* Other improvements in gazebo build time:  there are ways of improving compilation time, like use of precompiled headers, play with the physical design of code to make things faster for the compiler, try other linkers/compilers, etc.
* Performance tweaks in release scripts. Review what is being run in jenkins and check if there is something we can take out or change to gain some seconds.

Feedback?
content.html:
Currently our release process especially for gazebo. Here are my thoughts about why is so slow and how can we improve it:

Why is currently slow?

  • It can only run in one of the jenkins slave nodes, where the credentials to upload packages to gazebosim and real repo packages.osrfoundation.org is hosted.
  • For gazebo, it can only be compiled using -j1 because of large amount of memory needed for multiple thread. This started when we add all the possible support (player, media libs, etc) inside the build.

What can be done to speed up the process?

  • Set up several machines to build packages. One option could be set up all slaves to build and upload packages to gazebosim and trigger a jenkins job at the node where the repo is hosted which will download the new package and set it up in the repo using reprepro.
  • Enable multiple compilation threads. This will need a research about why are we using those large amounts of memory and see if they are really needed. I suspect that sometimes we are abusing of linking libraries not needed. And, of course, the easy way, buy more memory.
  • Other improvements in gazebo build time: there are ways of improving compilation time, like use of precompiled headers, play with the physical design of code to make things faster for the compiler, try other linkers/compilers, etc.
  • Performance tweaks in release scripts. Review what is being run in jenkins and check if there is something we can take out or change to gain some seconds.

Feedback?

values.title: Sanity checks for running release.py script

content.raw:
When someone is using the release.py script to launch package buildings there is a good number of things which could drive the generation to fail. 

First brainstorm of checks I would consider useful:

1. Version provided is not exactly the same as one in top of changelogs of {sofware]-release repos.
1. Version already exists in the repository or source package exists in assets.
1. Package name do not correspond to the software being packaged.
1. Package alias do not correspond with proper {software}-release branch (prerelease o nightly).
1. Inconsistencies between software dependencies (control file) among branches: not the same dependencies in release, nightly and default.
1. Same version in dependencies (control file) for different distributions (i.e: boost for precise and quantal).
content.html:
When someone is using the release.py script to launch package buildings there is a good number of things which could drive the generation to fail.

First brainstorm of checks I would consider useful:

  1. Version provided is not exactly the same as one in top of changelogs of {sofware]-release repos.
  2. Version already exists in the repository or source package exists in assets.
  3. Package name do not correspond to the software being packaged.
  4. Package alias do not correspond with proper {software}-release branch (prerelease o nightly).
  5. Inconsistencies between software dependencies (control file) among branches: not the same dependencies in release, nightly and default.
  6. Same version in dependencies (control file) for different distributions (i.e: boost for precise and quantal).

values.title: no DRI detected on real-vrc Jenkins slave

content.raw:
Looks like X-dependent tests are not running on the `real-vrc` slave.  E.g., in a [recent build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/drcsim/job/drcsim-default-gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64/163/consoleText), I see this:

    -- Looking for display capabilities
    --  + found a display available ($DISPLAY is set)
    --  ! valid dri display not found

That build runs the drcsim test suite, which [includes some tests](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/src/084739a7530dd022180fee281b1d5ccffc6bbeb6/ros/atlas_utils/test/CMakeLists.txt?at=default) that are only run when `glxinfo` can be successfully run.  

Looks like both techniques (the one in gazebo and the one in drcsim) are determining that X isn't running or can't be accessed.  Perhaps it's a machine misconfiguration.

Definitely need to get this working, so that all of our tests are running.

As a side issue, if it's easy to convert my glxinfo check to the more complete check that's used in gazebo, that would be nice.

-- Looking for display capabilities
--  + found a display available ($DISPLAY is set)
--  ! valid dri display not found

That build runs the drcsim test suite, which includes some tests that are only run when glxinfo can be successfully run.

Looks like both techniques (the one in gazebo and the one in drcsim) are determining that X isn't running or can't be accessed. Perhaps it's a machine misconfiguration.

Definitely need to get this working, so that all of our tests are running.

As a side issue, if it's easy to convert my glxinfo check to the more complete check that's used in gazebo, that would be nice.

values.title: Make version requirement on -nightly debs strict

content.raw:
See [drcsim #262](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/262/drcsim-nightly-is-busted).  If possible, each -nightly package should depend on **exactly** the versions (with their `hgXXXX` strings) of the underlying -nightly packages.  That way,  updating and installing a higher-level package will force an update to the underlying stuff.

This is how the old ROS build farm worked, by strict version-locking the debs.  We don't want to do that in general, but if possible, we ought to do it for the -nightly debs.
content.html:
See drcsim #262. If possible, each -nightly package should depend on exactly the versions (with their hgXXXX strings) of the underlying -nightly packages. That way, updating and installing a higher-level package will force an update to the underlying stuff.

This is how the old ROS build farm worked, by strict version-locking the debs. We don't want to do that in general, but if possible, we ought to do it for the -nightly debs.

values.title: Night ABI checking on version branches

content.raw:
ABI checking is only done when someone creates a new pull request. There is a risk of not using it right if later changes go into the pull request. A more robust method of checking is needed. Some ideas:

1. Make a nightly check of ABI on the supported branches (suggested by @scpeters).
1. Make ABI run on continuous integration of changes into main branches, in the same way that testing is done in devel-default jobs.
1. Improve our bitjen server to check for changes on PR and rerun the ABI checker. 

Proposals 1 and 2 are easy to implement. Proposal 3 would be nice, I've already started the work but still needs some love.
content.html:
ABI checking is only done when someone creates a new pull request. There is a risk of not using it right if later changes go into the pull request. A more robust method of checking is needed. Some ideas:

  1. Make a nightly check of ABI on the supported branches (suggested by @scpeters).
  2. Make ABI run on continuous integration of changes into main branches, in the same way that testing is done in devel-default jobs.
  3. Improve our bitjen server to check for changes on PR and rerun the ABI checker.

Proposals 1 and 2 are easy to implement. Proposal 3 would be nice, I've already started the work but still needs some love.

This error was after applying [the patch of removing dlclose](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/1026/osx-seg-faults-during-plugin-teardown#comment-7972838) so they don't segfault on MacOsX. And seems the one described in the [protobuf bug tracker](https://code.google.com/p/protobuf/issues/detail?id=370), still unresolved.

**Current working case and workarounds:**

@scpeters was able to run the testsuite without this errors (and I confirm it) from our t1000 machine using a catkin isolated workspace.

As a workaround, I have a [homebrew version of protobuf](https://github.com/j-rivero/homebrew-protobuf/blob/master/protobuf.rb) using the [patch](https://code.google.com/p/protobuf/issues/attachmentText?id=370&aid=3700010000&name=quick_patch.diff&token=TmdAgBMCRmuK9P9dGWQAsj_RB4A%3A1392686153119) described in the upstream issue and I can confirm that it is working fine in our jenkins.

A good point would be to found what is different between the catkin workspace environment in t1000 and my local machine / jenkins.

values.title: Clear .gazebo/models cache for home-brew jobs

content.raw:
I've been looking at persistent test failures recently, specifically [gzTest.SDF](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/homebrew/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew_bcn-amd64/101/testReport/(root)/gzTest/SDF/). It's a test that expects `gzsdf print` of a world file to match a shasum. That test passes on my local machine. I ran a test build with [additional debugging print statements](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/41/), and I noticed two lines that differ in the definition of the sun model.

The short version is that the home-brew jenkins machines have an old cache of gazebo models and it's causing this test to fail. I just cleared the `~jenkins/.gazebo/models` folder on t1000 and started a new build, which should fix the failing test.

We should clear the `~/.gazebo/models` folder in the home-brew jenkins scripts to keep the cache from getting outdated.
content.html:
I've been looking at persistent test failures recently, specifically gzTest.SDF. It's a test that expects gzsdf print of a world file to match a shasum. That test passes on my local machine. I ran a test build with additional debugging print statements, and I noticed two lines that differ in the definition of the sun model.

The short version is that the home-brew jenkins machines have an old cache of gazebo models and it's causing this test to fail. I just cleared the ~jenkins/.gazebo/models folder on t1000 and started a new build, which should fix the failing test.

We should clear the ~/.gazebo/models folder in the home-brew jenkins scripts to keep the cache from getting outdated.

values.title: Make gpu testing jobs fail if no gpu is found

content.raw: The gpu testing jobs often can't find the gpu, and they don't complain about it. I think we should make them fail or provide a big warning message when the gpu isn't found.
content.html: The gpu testing jobs often can't find the gpu, and they don't complain about it. I think we should make them fail or provide a big warning message when the gpu isn't found.

values.title: Add MSVC flags to windows compilations

content.raw:
There are at least two levels to do add windows compilations flags:

* We can follow the current way of doing it for UNIX and add a CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS directive to our cmake files in the case of using MSVC.

* We can add the flags to our release-tools script, at the time of running cmake.

I would prefer the first option if we can not find a good reason to use the second one.

  • We can follow the current way of doing it for UNIX and add a CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS directive to our cmake files in the case of using MSVC.

  • We can add the flags to our release-tools script, at the time of running cmake.

I would prefer the first option if we can not find a good reason to use the second one.

values.title: Over-writing release hg tags

content.raw:
I ran into a problem with while packaging sdformat 2.0.1 for Fedora, where the hg tag corresponsing to the 2.0.1 release seems to have moved.  I grabbed source corresponding to the sdformat2_2.0.1 tag at the end of August, with hg hash 7899c38774ac. Since then, it looks like the tag has moved a couple of times, and now points to d79259b which includes a fix to install the sdformat-version cmake file that was missing from the august tarball.

It's my understanding that the tag shifting was a bug with the release tools, and that they should be updated to not overwrite tags that already exist.

values.title: Check osx machines for running xquartz

content.raw:
I just noticed that some of the gazebo homebrew builds are not running the GPU tests, for example [this one](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/460/):
~~~
-- Looking for display capabilities
--  ! valid display not found
--  ! valid dri display not found (no glxinfo or pyopengl)
~~~
I logged in to the machine and saw that xquartz was not running (first column should be PID, not `-`):
~~~
$ launchctl list | grep xquartz
-	0	org.macosforge.xquartz.startx
~~~

I restarted xquartz manually:
~~~
$ launchctl start org.macosforge.xquartz.startx
$ launchctl list | grep xquartz
40138	-	org.macosforge.xquartz.startx
~~~

We should checks to the homebrew jobs if we want a display to be present and fail if it is missing.

values.title: Relieving backlog in build machines

content.raw:
We are getting some backlog in Jenkins, especially when there are hanging jobs.

Can we enable the code_check script in homebrew, utopic, and coverage jobs? I believe they aren't currently running.

Also, the `gazebo-any-coverage` job requires `trusty-gpu-nvidia`, so it is redundant with the `gazebo-any-devel-trusty-gpu-nvidia` job. Perhaps we can trigger the non-GPU trusty job instead, so it can run on a different machine and give faster feedback about failures?

values.title: Clean up disk space after jenkins build

content.raw:
Speaking with @scpeters, we agree that we are facing the problem of disk usage to host all the jenkins builds. In order to solve this problem, several measures can be done:

 * Host only N number of builds in the jenkins jobs. This should be already done for the most of our jobs.
 * Clean up all the build intermediate artifacts and other download files.
    *  Gazebo default job in Linux is already doing this (remove the build directory)
content.html:
Speaking with @scpeters, we agree that we are facing the problem of disk usage to host all the jenkins builds. In order to solve this problem, several measures can be done:

  • Host only N number of builds in the jenkins jobs. This should be already done for the most of our jobs.
  • Clean up all the build intermediate artifacts and other download files.
    • Gazebo default job in Linux is already doing this (remove the build directory)

values.title: Repeat failed tests to identify flaky ones?

content.raw:
`ctest` has an option to repeat any failed tests (`--rerun-failed`). This could be used to identify flaky tests. It would take some work to manage the results files, since there would be duplicates of the repeated tests.

Perhaps it could work as follows:

1. Run `make test`, which will create junit files in the `test_results` folder.

2. Copy the `test_results` folder to `test_results_original`.

3. Run `make test ARGS="--rerun-failed"`, which will run the failed tests once more and over-write the junit files in `test_results`.

4. Repeat step 3 as desired.

Running this procedure should lead to a strictly decreasing number of test failures in `test_results`, since any tests that pass at least once will be shown as passing in the junit files in `test_results`. Any tests that failed in `test_results_original` but pass in `test_results` are flaky tests.

The Jenkins U/I would need a new element to display information about flaky tests, and we would also need some new logic to compare the results of `test_results_original` with `test_results`.
content.html:
ctest has an option to repeat any failed tests (--rerun-failed). This could be used to identify flaky tests. It would take some work to manage the results files, since there would be duplicates of the repeated tests.

Perhaps it could work as follows:

  1. Run make test, which will create junit files in the test_results folder.

  2. Copy the test_results folder to test_results_original.

  3. Run make test ARGS="--rerun-failed", which will run the failed tests once more and over-write the junit files in test_results.

  4. Repeat step 3 as desired.

Running this procedure should lead to a strictly decreasing number of test failures in test_results, since any tests that pass at least once will be shown as passing in the junit files in test_results. Any tests that failed in test_results_original but pass in test_results are flaky tests.

The Jenkins U/I would need a new element to display information about flaky tests, and we would also need some new logic to compare the results of test_results_original with test_results.

values.title: flaky_junit_merge has trouble with tests that fail to run

content.raw:
We use the [check_test_ran.py](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/a0e43939bd9tools/tools/check_test_ran.py) script to generate a junit xml file for tests that fail to generate an xml output. For example, a passing test will generate the following:

~~~
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<testsuites tests="5" failures="0" disabled="0" errors="0" timestamp="2016-03-30T11:18:28" time="0.004" name="AllTests">
  <testsuite name="RandTest" tests="5" failures="0" disabled="0" errors="0" time="0.004">
    <testcase name="Rand1" status="run" time="0" classname="RandTest" />
    <testcase name="Rand2" status="run" time="0" classname="RandTest" />
    <testcase name="Fail" status="run" time="0" classname="RandTest" />
    <testcase name="Rand" status="run" time="0" classname="RandTest" />
    <testcase name="SetSeed" status="run" time="0.004" classname="RandTest" />
  </testsuite>
</testsuites>
~~~

While a test that seg-faults would have the following generated by `check_test_ran.py`:
~~~
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<testsuite tests="1" failures="1" time="1" errors="0" name="UNIT_Rand_TEST.xml">
  <testcase name="test_ran" status="run" time="1" classname="Results">
    <failure message="Unable to find test results for UNIT_Rand_TEST.xml, test did not run.
Expected results in test_results/UNIT_Rand_TEST.xml" type=""/>
  </testcase>
</testsuite>
~~~

The `flaky_junit_merge` script doesn't handle this well because it expects two junit files to have `<testsuite>` and `<testcase>` tags with matching names.
content.html:
We use the check_test_ran.py script to generate a junit xml file for tests that fail to generate an xml output. For example, a passing test will generate the following:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<testsuites tests="5" failures="0" disabled="0" errors="0" timestamp="2016-03-30T11:18:28" time="0.004" name="AllTests">
  <testsuite name="RandTest" tests="5" failures="0" disabled="0" errors="0" time="0.004">
    <testcase name="Rand1" status="run" time="0" classname="RandTest" />
    <testcase name="Rand2" status="run" time="0" classname="RandTest" />
    <testcase name="Fail" status="run" time="0" classname="RandTest" />
    <testcase name="Rand" status="run" time="0" classname="RandTest" />
    <testcase name="SetSeed" status="run" time="0.004" classname="RandTest" />
  </testsuite>
</testsuites>

While a test that seg-faults would have the following generated by check_test_ran.py:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<testsuite tests="1" failures="1" time="1" errors="0" name="UNIT_Rand_TEST.xml">
  <testcase name="test_ran" status="run" time="1" classname="Results">
    <failure message="Unable to find test results for UNIT_Rand_TEST.xml, test did not run.
Expected results in test_results/UNIT_Rand_TEST.xml" type=""/>
  </testcase>
</testsuite>

The flaky_junit_merge script doesn't handle this well because it expects two junit files to have <testsuite> and <testcase> tags with matching names.

values.title: Deadlock with orchestration

content.raw:
Tonight there were 5 `gazebo-ci-pr_any` jobs that were part running on maria.local, mostly waiting for executors to come available to start the different jobs. It reached the nightly reboot time, though, which prevents new jobs from starting. This appeared to be a deadlock situation, in which it would wait for ever for those jobs to finish, but they would never do so. I took the liberty of doing a forced restart, which allowed things to proceed.

We should think if there's a way to eliminate this deadlock.

values.title: Gazebo nightly build race condition with uploader

content.raw:
One of the gazebo nightly builds failed recently because it was running concurrently with the uploader for the nightly sdformat deb:

* The [sdformat nightly build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/debbuild/job/sdformat4-debbuilder/883/) ran first

and triggered the 

* [repository uploader job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/debbuild/job/repository_uploader_ng/1976/) and
* [gazebo nightly build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo8-debbuilder/236/), which failed because the uploader job changed the apt repository (yesterday's sdformat nightly build was deleted) between the time the gazebo deb builder did `apt-get update` and `apt-get install`
content.html:
One of the gazebo nightly builds failed recently because it was running concurrently with the uploader for the nightly sdformat deb:

  • The sdformat nightly build ran first

and triggered the

  • repository uploader job and
  • gazebo nightly build, which failed because the uploader job changed the apt repository (yesterday's sdformat nightly build was deleted) between the time the gazebo deb builder did apt-get update and apt-get install

values.title: Problems with permissions on pre-clean

content.raw:
After pull request #232, which implements the pre-clean of workspace for all the artifact results, there are some problems when build are aborted and the [final piece of code](#!/osrf/release-tools/src/c63eaf36d8f7c7a2e713fd9a19f0427fa35b3ab1/jenkins-scripts/docker/lib/docker_run.bash?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#docker_run.bash-38) which changes permissions from root to jenkins is not being run.

Example of [failed build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/444/console):
```
[WS-CLEANUP] Deleting project workspace...
ERROR: [WS-CLEANUP] Cannot delete workspace: remote file operation failed: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia at hudson.remoting.Channel@59117489:r2d2.nv.trusty: java.nio.file.AccessDeniedException: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/build/cppcheck_results/cppcheck-configuration.xml
```

The workspace cleanup option allows to specify a custom command for deleting the files, I tried to setup the remove command using sudo (`sudo rm -fr %s`) but did not make any difference. If I go into the machine using ssh and run the sudo command, the directory is removed without any problem.

I've implement a [minimal test case](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/_test_io_access_cleanup/configure) of generating a file with root perms but surprisingly the [cleanup step can remove it] just fine without sudo or any other thing. Going into the filesystem using ssh with the jenkins user can not clean it up.
content.html:
After pull request #232, which implements the pre-clean of workspace for all the artifact results, there are some problems when build are aborted and the final piece of code which changes permissions from root to jenkins is not being run.

Example of failed build:

[WS-CLEANUP] Deleting project workspace...
ERROR: [WS-CLEANUP] Cannot delete workspace: remote file operation failed: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia at hudson.remoting.Channel@59117489:r2d2.nv.trusty: java.nio.file.AccessDeniedException: /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/build/cppcheck_results/cppcheck-configuration.xml

The workspace cleanup option allows to specify a custom command for deleting the files, I tried to setup the remove command using sudo (sudo rm -fr %s) but did not make any difference. If I go into the machine using ssh and run the sudo command, the directory is removed without any problem.

I've implement a minimal test case of generating a file with root perms but surprisingly the [cleanup step can remove it] just fine without sudo or any other thing. Going into the filesystem using ssh with the jenkins user can not clean it up.

values.title: Old sdformat-sdf debs are not archived

content.raw: @dljsjr was recently trying to regenerate an sdformat file using `gz sdf` using the drcsim version of gazebo4, which uses libsdformat 2.3.2, but when installing those debs, the sdformat definitions come from the sdformat-sdf 4.1.0 deb. I managed to find an older [sdformat-sdf 2.3.2 deb](http://packages.ros.org/ros/ubuntu/pool/main/s/sdformat2/sdformat-sdf_2.3.2-1~trusty_all.deb) on packages.ros.org, so we found a workaround, but it would be nice if we archived some of these old `sdformat-sdf` packages, even if the newest version is the only one that would be used.
content.html: @dljsjr was recently trying to regenerate an sdformat file using gz sdf using the drcsim version of gazebo4, which uses libsdformat 2.3.2, but when installing those debs, the sdformat definitions come from the sdformat-sdf 4.1.0 deb. I managed to find an older sdformat-sdf 2.3.2 deb on packages.ros.org, so we found a workaround, but it would be nice if we archived some of these old sdformat-sdf packages, even if the newest version is the only one that would be used.

values.title: Linuxbrew now requires ruby 2.0

content.raw:
We have a couple jenkins jobs that use Linuxbrew to create and modify homebrew pull requests. Recently ([Aug 16](https://github.com/Linuxbrew/brew/commit/179ef2bf8cb1fb24622c917ea8d9a7cad70d5de5)), Linuxbrew was updated to require ruby 2 or higher. This has caused failures on jenkins, since our jenkins node is configured to use ruby 1.9:

* http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/generic-release-homebrew_pr_bottle_hash_updater/66/console
content.html:
We have a couple jenkins jobs that use Linuxbrew to create and modify homebrew pull requests. Recently (Aug 16), Linuxbrew was updated to require ruby 2 or higher. This has caused failures on jenkins, since our jenkins node is configured to use ruby 1.9:

values.title: Mark bottle builds unstable if possible

content.raw: Sometimes bottles build successfully, but `brew test-bot` complains that downstream bottles are still broken (for example with this [simbody build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder/84/console)). It would be nice if that job was marked as unstable and the bottle and json file were exposed as artifacts. The downstream jobs could be skipped, but it would at least be nice to download those bottles for manual upload.

The downstream jobs could be skipped, but it would at least be nice to download those bottles for manual upload.

values.title: Test homebrew bottles regularly

content.raw:
I have observed several of our bottles fail when dependencies are update (most recently boost and protobuf). It would be nice to test our bottles regularly so we can detect when breakages occur and rebuild the bottles.

The [gazebo-install-one_liner-homebrew-amd64](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-install-one_liner-homebrew-amd64/) job currently does this for the gazebo7 formula (cleanup, brew install gazebo7, brew test gazebo7); it would be nice to run the same thing for a curated list of supported formulae:

* gazebo[567]
* ignition-math2
* ignition-msgs
* ignition-transport2?
* ogre
* sdformat[34]?
* simbody
content.html:

values.title: Add short delay before starting ci-pr_any jobs

content.raw:
We currently have a pattern of updating the Changelog with pull request number immediately after making a pull request. The bitbucket watch starts the jenkins jobs and updates the build status very quickly, so the pull requests don't show up on the main pull request screen.

For example:

* build status not visible on [main page](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2480/qt-render-events-default/diff)
* though it is visible on the [commits page](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2480/qt-render-events-default/commits)

If we had a delay of 30 seconds or a minute that would give time to update the changelog.

cc: @nkoenig
content.html:
We currently have a pattern of updating the Changelog with pull request number immediately after making a pull request. The bitbucket watch starts the jenkins jobs and updates the build status very quickly, so the pull requests don't show up on the main pull request screen.

For example:

  • build status not visible on main page
  • though it is visible on the commits page

If we had a delay of 30 seconds or a minute that would give time to update the changelog.

cc: @nkoenig

values.title: homebrew tests failing due to missing boost symbol

content.raw:
There have been 240+ test failures in the homebrew tests run in `t1000` since a few days ago. The tests complain about missing boost symbols:

~~~
1: dyld: Symbol not found: __ZNK5boost16re_detail_10620031cpp_regex_traits_implementationIcE17transform_primaryEPKcS4_
1:   Referenced from: /usr/local/opt/sdformat4/lib/libsdformat.4.dylib
1:   Expected in: /usr/local/opt/boost/lib/libboost_regex-mt.dylib
1:  in /usr/local/opt/sdformat4/lib/libsdformat.4.dylib
~~~

This has been happening on `gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64`, `gazebo-ci-gazebo7-homebrew-amd64` and `gazebo-ci-default-homebrew-amd64`, so I'm ticketing it here because I think the homebrew testing machine might be in a weird state.

values.title: Jobs for PRs targeted at Gazebo 7 with sdformat4

content.raw:
I haven't been able to find any jobs for checking PRs targeted at the gazebo7 branch. If I run the `gazebo-ci-pr_any` branches the job will build sdformat5, and the `configure gazebo` step fails with the following. 


```
#!

-- BUILD ERRORS: These must be resolved before compiling.
-- 	Missing: SDF version >=4.1.0. Required for reading and writing SDF files.
-- END BUILD ERRORS
```
content.html:
I haven't been able to find any jobs for checking PRs targeted at the gazebo7 branch. If I run the gazebo-ci-pr_any branches the job will build sdformat5, and the configure gazebo step fails with the following. 

-- BUILD ERRORS: These must be resolved before compiling.
--  Missing: SDF version >=4.1.0. Required for reading and writing SDF files.
-- END BUILD ERRORS

values.title: nvidia-docker has problems with Ogre on the Trusty node (r2d2)

content.raw:
The r2d2 node has been registering problems to run properly the GPU testing since we update the system to use nvidia-docker.

As an example, the [robocup3ds](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/robocup3ds/job/robocup3ds-install-one_liner-trusty-amd64/497/console) is failing with the error:

```
[Err] [WindowManager.cc:128] EXCEPTION: Unable to create the rendering window

[Err] [RenderingIface.cc:38] Failed to load the Rendering engine subsystem
Unable to create the rendering window
```
content.html:
The r2d2 node has been registering problems to run properly the GPU testing since we update the system to use nvidia-docker.

As an example, the robocup3ds is failing with the error:

[Err] [WindowManager.cc:128] EXCEPTION: Unable to create the rendering window

[Err] [RenderingIface.cc:38] Failed to load the Rendering engine subsystem
Unable to create the rendering window

values.title: [build cop] sdformat trusty failed to fetch package from archive

content.raw:
Copied from https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/2184/build-cop-sdformat-trusty-failed-to-featch

http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/BuildCopTests/job/sdformat-ci-default-trusty-amd64/46/

```
Err http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ trusty-security/main linux-libc-dev amd64 3.13.0-107.154
  404  Not Found [IP: 91.189.88.161 80]
Fetched 101 MB in 3min 5s (547 kB/s)
W: Duplicate sources.list entry http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ trusty-updates/main amd64 Packages (/var/lib/apt/lists/archive.ubuntu.com_ubuntu_dists_trusty-updates_main_binary-amd64_Packages.gz)
W: Duplicate sources.list entry http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ trusty-updates/restricted amd64 Packages (/var/lib/apt/lists/archive.ubuntu.com_ubuntu_dists_trusty-updates_restricted_binary-amd64_Packages.gz)
W: Duplicate sources.list entry http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ trusty-updates/universe amd64 Packages (/var/lib/apt/lists/archive.ubuntu.com_ubuntu_dists_trusty-updates_universe_binary-amd64_Packages.gz)
W: You may want to run apt-get update to correct these problems
E: Failed to fetch http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/pool/main/l/linux/linux-libc-dev_3.13.0-107.154_amd64.deb  404  Not Found [IP: 91.189.88.161 80]

E: Unable to fetch some archives, maybe run apt-get update or try with --fix-missing?
```

Looks like the docker layer that installs packages was separate from the layer that updates the package list. I'm testing a fix in http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/BuildCopTests/job/sdformat-ci-default-trusty-amd64/48/
